page.title: 04Dialect
page.content: As in all other parts of the country this area has its own dialect which is fully understood only by those native to the place,and even they might have difficulty in grasping the meaning of some of the farmers' conversations. Among other things,less printable than the following,you will hear "gey" used for "very" and "yon" for "that". The old words "thee" and "thou" tend to be used often."Ewe" is pronounced as "yow" and "pasture" as "passter".A local boy will leave his friends to "gan yam" rather than "go home". A farmer who has cows to take to the local auction has "beast t' tek t't mart".Another expression is "Seesther" which means "Seest thou?" or "Look at that".A freer translation for this all -purpose phrase would be "xxxxx!" When poultry is prepared for market it is plucked.In this area it is "ploated".
